description: From Middle English orte, from Old English *orǣta (“that which is left after eating”, literally “out-eat”), equivalent to or- +‎ eat. Cognate with Middle Low German orte (“refuse of food”), Middle Dutch ooraete, ooreete, Low German ort (“ort”), Middle High German urez, German Uräß.

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) A fragment; a scrap of leftover food; any remainder; a piece of refuse.

verbs.description: ort (third-person singular simple present orts, present participle orting, simple past and past participle orted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, dialectal) To turn away from with disgust; refuse.
